author: By Erica L. Green and Michael D. Shear
title: Musk Wields Scythe on Federal Work Force, With Trump’s Full Blessing
description: The president defended Elon Musk’s role in seeking to slash budgets and cut payrolls as the young aides burrowing into federal agencies came under scrutiny.
content: Follow today’s live coverage of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 608
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Feb. 8, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Kamala Harris Tours the Destruction in the Palisades
description: Asked during her visit on Thursday if she was considering running for governor of California, Ms. Harris did not give a direct answer, but did not rule it out either.
content: Former Vice President Kamala Harris toured fire damage in Pacific Palisades on Thursday and met with local officials, her first visit to the neighborhood since the devastating wildfires last month and one of her few public appearances since leaving office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: When a Bar Closes, Who Gets the Neon Sign?
description: After the decades-old Subway Inn shut down, the new tenant took down its sign. The Subway Inn’s former operator said he had no right to do so.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a fight over a once familiar neon sign on the Upper East Side. We’ll also get details on a federal investigation involving Shen Yun Performing Arts, the touring dance group run by the Falun Gong religious movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Federal Election Commission Chair Says Trump Has Moved to Fire Her
description: Ellen L. Weintraub, who has served as a commissioner for the nation’s top elections watchdog since 2002, said she did not recognize a letter from President Trump relieving her from her post as legally valid.
content: Ellen L. Weintraub, the chairwoman of the Federal Election Commission, said on Thursday that President Trump had moved to fire her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Behind Closed Doors, Trudeau Says Trump Threat to Take Over Canada Is Real
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, in a talk with business leaders, said Canada’s wealth of critical minerals are behind Mr. Trump’s comments about making its northern neighbor a U.S. state.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada on Friday made his first comments in response to President Trump’s repeated statements that he wants to annex Canada and make it the 51st state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Wall Street Prepares to Defend a Favored Tax Break, Again
description: President Trump called for ending the so-called carried interest loophole, which saves financiers billions. It’s a tax break that has survived time after time.
content: We’ve got a whirlwind of news out of Washington — the carried interest tax exemption in the cross hairs, the latest on DOGE and an update on settlement talks between CBS and President Trump — but you should also pay attention to this news out of Washington State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Dozens of Live Beetles Found in Japanese Snacks During Customs Check at LAX
description: The insects were most likely intended for exotic insect collections, according to customs officials, who say the illegal pet trade is flourishing.
content: The chocolates, potato chips and other colorful snacks that arrived as cargo at Los Angeles International Airport from Japan last month looked tempting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Campus Figures
description: Kelly Morenus opens our solving weekend.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: A Sick Inmate in New York Is Freed After Suing Over Parole Delay
description: Steve Coleman was kept for 21 months after his parole date because the state could not find a nursing home placement.
content: A sick man was released from a New York prison on Friday after suing the state for keeping him long past his parole date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Europe’s Trump Playbook: Offer Carrots but Warn That You Have a Big Stick
description: The European Union’s so-called Trump task force spent 2024 preparing for a possible trade dispute. Specifics are secret, but guiding principles are becoming clear.
content: The European Union spent last year drawing up secret plans for what the bloc would do if President Trump made good on his threats of imposing higher tariffs on European goods and services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump’s Gaza Deal: War Crimes in Exchange for Beachfront Property
description: The president’s proposal wasn’t serious, but it was dangerous.
content: When Donald Trump, speaking beside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, announced this week that the United States would be taking over Gaza and “permanently” resettling its population elsewhere, few in American politics took him seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Doechii’s Victory Lap, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks from Valerie June, Coi Leray, Destroyer and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Worlds Collide to Make a Big Ballet Bang
description: Alexei Ratmansky creates a joyful new “Paquita” for New York City Ballet, giving the dancers a classical frame in which to find new versions of themselves.
content: It’s a test tube ballet: an experiment that at first glance might seem like pining for the past. But while Alexei Ratmansky’s new production of “Paquita” finds its footing from ballets of earlier centuries, it lands in the here and now as a daring proposal about legacy and lineage. What makes classical dancing modern? In this case, it’s placing a conceptual lens on tradition. Mercifully, with tutus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Abdalrahman Altayeb
title: Fighting Intensifies in Sudan, Leaving Hundreds Dead
description: The army and the paramilitary forces are locked in a new and ruinous battle for territory across the northeast African nation.
content: Hundreds of people, including dozens of children, have been killed in Sudan in recent days, according to civilian witnesses, medical workers and the United Nations, as fierce clashes have escalated in an internal conflict that is approaching its third year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How a Family’s Life Is Upended in ‘I’m Still Here’
description: The film’s director, Walter Salles, narrates a sequence from his film, which is nominated for best picture. Its star, Fernanda Torres is nominated for best actress.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Treasury Installs Musk Ally to Oversee Its Payment System
description: Tom Krause, a software executive, is the Treasury Department’s fiscal assistant secretary with access to a system that disburses government funds and includes Americans’ personal information.
content: The Treasury Department installed an ally of Elon Musk in a key position overseeing the nation’s payment system, replacing a career civil servant who had resisted granting Mr. Musk’s cost-cutting team access to payments data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Defended Musk’s Cost-Cutting Effort
description: Also, a judge paused job cuts at U.S.A.I.D. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: President Trump offered praise today for Elon Musk and his team at the so-called Department of Government Efficiency, who have led the administration’s effort to purge federal workers. He said he had directed them to search across the government for costs to eliminate. He mentioned in particular that Musk would scrutinize spending at the Pentagon, from which Musk has received at least $3.6 billion in contracts over the past decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Kate Conger
title: Vance and Trump Call for Rehiring of DOGE Staffer Who Quit Over Racist Posts. Musk Obliges.
description: Soon after Mr. Trump’s remarks, Elon Musk wrote on X that the employee, Marko Elez, would be rehired.
content: Vice President JD Vance on Friday morning called for the reinstatement of a Department of Government Efficiency staff member who had resigned after being linked to racist posts he made on X under a pseudonym — a position endorsed hours later by President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump Says Nippon Steel Will Make Major Investment in U.S. Steel
description: President Trump supports the Japanese company’s taking a stake in the American steel maker after the U.S. blocked a $14 billion takeover bid.
content: President Trump said on Friday that Nippon Steel was planning to make a major investment in U.S. Steel after the Biden administration moved to block the Japanese company’s $14 billion takeover bid last month on the basis that it was a threat to national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Damien
title: ‘He’s Just Old and Homeless’: California Jail Death Leads to Accusations of Neglect
description: Court-appointed monitors of Sacramento County jails say a man’s fatal overdose was one of multiple deaths in which deputies and nurses exhibited a “callous” indifference toward detainees.
content: A Sacramento man suffering from a drug overdose was neglected by a police officer, medical workers and sheriff’s deputies over the course of more than two hours before he died at a county jail last May, according to reports from court-appointed monitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Eve Sampson
title: The Military Led Diversity Efforts. West Point’s Club Ban Is a Shift.
description: West Point leaders complied with President Trump’s D.E.I. ban by ending a dozen student clubs. Critics say the move contradicts decades of efforts to diversify the nation’s fighting force.
content: Vincent Vu helped found the Vietnamese-American Cadet Association at the United States Military Academy at West Point while he was a cadet, in 2015. West Point’s culture could be difficult for someone like him, who did not come from a military background, he recalled this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump Says He Will Announce Reciprocal Tariffs Next Week
description: The president said he planned to impose tariffs on countries that tax U.S. products. He also paused an action against China, allowing its low-cost products to again enter the U.S. tariff free.
content: President Trump indicated he was ready to broaden his trade war on Friday, saying that he would announce reciprocal tariffs on other countries next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and James Wagner
title: How Much Can 10,000 Mexican Troops Achieve at the Border?
description: To stave off U.S. tariffs, Mexico agreed to deploy 10,000 troops to its northern border. Analysts and former officials question whether they can effectively stop the flow of fentanyl.
content: During his latest presidential campaign, President Trump bragged about compelling Mexico to deploy 28,000 troops to its borders during his first administration to avoid tariffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Should Your Partner Really Be Your Best Friend?
description: Expecting a spouse to be both friend and lover is a relatively new concept. Some think it’s asking too much.
content: Stephanie Lopez is effusive about her husband’s good qualities. He is a man of character, kindness and integrity, she said. He is a loving father and treats her with respect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Howard Twilley, Super Bowl Scorer for Undefeated Miami, Dies at 81
description: After a stellar college football career, he spent 11 years with the Dolphins. He caught a touchdown pass in 1973 that concluded the team’s 17-0 season.
content: Howard Twilley, a key receiver for the Miami Dolphins during the team’s perfect 1972 season and a Heisman Trophy runner-up at the University of Tulsa, died on Wednesday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Ecuador’s President Has Had a Year of Chaos. Why Is He Still So Popular?
description: President Daniel Noboa is favored to win Sunday’s presidential election as many voters embrace his heavy-handed tactics to fight violence and corruption.
content: Daniel Noboa was nowhere to be seen. And, yet, he was everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: Can Movie Stars Handle Greek Classics? London Is Finding Out.
description: Sophocles is suddenly everywhere on the city’s stages. In concurrent shows, Rami Malek is playing Oedipus and Brie Larson is taking on Elektra.
content: At the Old Vic theater in London, a tenebrous stage is lit now and again with deep, yellowy-orange hues; at its center is a stark solar orb. The effect is soothing, like being gently woken by an enormous sunrise alarm. The setting is a drought-stricken Thebes and the play is a reimagining of Sophocles’ tragedy, “Oedipus Rex,” first performed around 429 B.C. and relevant as ever in our era of vainglorious leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Alexander Brothers Plead Not Guilty in Sex Trafficking Case
description: Real estate brokers Tal and Oren Alexander, along with their brother Alon Alexander, are charged with drugging and assaulting multiple women.
content: Three brothers who were once fixtures of the nightlife circuits in Miami and New York pleaded not guilty on Friday to federal sex trafficking conspiracy charges in a Manhattan courtroom. The federal trial of Tal, Oren and Alon Alexander has been set for January 2026.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Kris Jenner Puts the ‘Keeping Up With the Kardashians’ House Up for Sale
description: The six-bedroom home in Los Angeles, where the family’s reality TV show was filmed for more than a decade, is being listed for $13.5 million.
content: A slice of television history is hitting the market: Kris Jenner, momager and matriarch of the Kardashian family, is selling the clan’s longtime family home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Blackened Salmon, Spiced Heavily and Seared Hard
description: That’s Saturday’s supper, with French toast amandine for breakfast and yakamein for lunch.
content: Good morning. This is not a big weekend for health food. People will fry chicken wings for the Super Bowl, make loaded nachos, chili, barbecued ribs. I’ll put out queso and chips, some stuffed jalapeños, maybe some brats, get everyone comfortable, ready to watch violence and advertising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: Trump’s New Line of Attack Against the Media Gains Momentum
description: First Amendment experts say Mr. Trump’s lawsuits, based on an unproven legal theory, lack merit. But more could be on the way.
content: Media lawyers scoffed last year when President Trump sued two news organizations for producing journalism that, he claimed, violated laws meant to protect consumers from things like deceptive advertising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Ramirez
title: ‘My Home Is on Fire. My Home Is on Fire.’
description: Daniel Ramirez, a Times audio engineer, writes about the trauma of losing everything in the Eaton fire.
content: You start to realize the difference between a house and a home when you’re watching it burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: ‘BACK TO PLASTIC’: Trump Vows to Keep the Government on Plastic Straws
description: The move would run counter to a Biden administration push to cut back on single-use plastic, which was considered a milestone.
content: President Trump said on Friday that he would stop a plan by the Biden administration to phase out plastic straws in favor of paper ones across the federal government, saying they don’t work and it’s “BACK TO PLASTIC.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Senate Confirms Russell Vought as Office of Management and Budget Director
description: Mr. Vought, an architect of Project 2025 who served in the first Trump administration, will be at the center of President Trump’s plans to upend the federal bureaucracy.
content: The Senate voted along party lines on Thursday to confirm Russell T. Vought to lead the Office of Management and Budget, putting in place one of the most powerful architects of President Trump’s agenda to upend the federal bureaucracy and slash spending that the administration thinks is wasteful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Three Super Bowl Titles, Two Podcasts and One Explosive Interview
description: “Club Shay Shay” became a must-stop destination for Hollywood after Katt Williams aired his grievances. “This was our ‘Thriller’ album,” said the host Shannon Sharpe.
content: Shannon Sharpe won three Super Bowls in a Hall of Fame career and once recorded 214 receiving yards in a game, the most ever by a National Football League tight end. Another crowning achievement came long after he was outmuscling bulky defenders, when he convinced a 5-foot-5 comedian to open up while sipping cognac on a brown leather sofa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: White House Forces Showdown Over Congress’s Power of the Purse
description: The confirmation of Russell T. Vought to lead the powerful White House budget office is likely to escalate the funding fights roiling Washington and the nation.
content: Susan Collins was a Senate intern in 1974 when Congress, in response to President Richard M. Nixon’s refusal to spend on projects he opposed, passed a sweeping budget law to bar presidents from overriding lawmakers when it came to doling out dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: California Asks Insurers to Spare Wildfire Victims ‘the List’
description: The state’s regulator wants insurance carriers to pay full policy limits without requiring victims to itemize every object in their destroyed homes.
content: California’s top insurance regulator urged insurance carriers on Thursday to pay policyholders the full amount of the belongings in their coverage without requiring them to itemize every object lost — an undertaking that has burdened thousands of residents whose homes were destroyed by wildfires last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: 22 States Sue to Block New York Law Targeting Fossil Fuel Companies
description: Emboldened by President Trump, West Virginia and other states are challenging the Climate Change Superfund Act, which makes corporate polluters pay for past emissions.
content: Twenty-two states, led by West Virginia, are suing to block a recently approved New York law that requires fossil fuel companies to pay billions of dollars a year for contributing to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Tree and Frames
description: Tell a story, real or made up, that connects three or more of the elements in this image.
content: What story could this image tell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Denounces Talk With U.S. but Seems to Leave Door Ajar
description: Both President Trump and Iranian officials have shown interest in negotiations. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called the idea unwise, but stopped short of ordering his government not to engage.
content: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said negotiating with the United States was “unwise, unintelligent, and not honorable,” just days after President Trump said he was willing to revive negotiations with Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko
title: At a Draft Site in Ukraine, an Anguished Wait for a Chance to Say Goodbye
description: The Ukrainian authorities are rounding up recruits. Relatives huddle at a center on the edge of Kyiv for a chance to see loved ones before they’re shipped to war.
content: They stand in a small crowd outside the large metal gate, tense and waiting in the dark. Most look weighed down, both by stress and by overstuffed plastic bags — all for men who may soon be heading off to war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Deportation Flights to Venezuela Will Begin ‘Within the Next 30 Days’
description: The assertion by Tom Homan, President Trump’s border czar, could herald a shift in the relationship between the United States and Venezuela’s autocrat, Nicolás Maduro.
content: President Trump’s border czar, Tom Homan, made plainly clear how a Latin American nation — considered a U.S. adversary — will help the president deliver on a promise that carried him to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 7, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 7, 2025.
content: Because of an editing error, an obituary about the Aga Khan IV, the leader of the world’s Ismaili Muslims, misstated a title given to Prince Rahim Al-Hussaini, the hereditary successor of the Aga Khan IV. He became the Aga Khan V, not the 50th. He is the 50th hereditary Imam, or spiritual leader, of the Shia Ismaili Muslims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Are You Worried About A.I. Taking Human Jobs?
description: A “Simpsons” voice actor is concerned about A.I. coming for his work. Should we all be?
content: The wisecracking Po in “Kung Fu Panda.” The conniving Gru from “Despicable Me." The spunky Fiona in “Shrek.” The thunderous Mufasa in “Lion King.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Alex Barron, Kate LoPresti, Wendy Dorr, Sophia Lanman, Elisheba Ittoop and Gilbert Cruz
title: How ‘Nickel Boys’ Became One of the Year’s Most Visually Striking Films
description: The director RaMell Ross on adapting Colson Whitehead’s prize-winning novel.
content: When the filmmaker and photographer RaMell Ross first read “The Nickel Boys,” Colson Whitehead’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about two Black boys in a dangerous reform school in the 1960s, he couldn’t help but put himself in the shoes of its protagonists, Elwood and Turner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Katy Reckdahl
title: After New Orleans’s Super Bowl Makeover, Some Residents Say: What About Us?
description: Streetlights and sidewalks have been installed. Broken pavement has been replaced. But residents say the work should continue after the Super Bowl leaves.
content: Even if there weren’t Super Bowl banners hanging from lamp posts and signs plastered across recently erected security fences, it would still be obvious that New Orleans was gussying up for a reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: The Senate G.O.P. unveils its own budget plan, teeing up a fight with the House.
description: House Republicans have been toiling unsuccessfully to reach agreement on a fiscal blueprint. Their Senate colleagues are leapfrogging ahead.
content: Senator Lindsey Graham on Friday unveiled a budget plan that would increase spending for the military and border security measures, in a move aimed at expediting President Trump’s agenda as House Republicans remained divided over their own massive fiscal package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: I.C.C. Denounces the Trump Order Imposing Sanctions on It
description: The International Criminal Court said President Trump’s executive order sought to harm its “independent and impartial judicial work.” Several European countries reaffirmed support for the body.
content: The International Criminal Court on Friday condemned President Trump’s executive order imposing sanctions on it, saying that the action sought to harm the court’s “independent and impartial judicial work.” Key European allies of the United States also distanced themselves from his decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Why Is Trump Targeting the International Criminal Court?
description: President Trump says the work of the I.C.C., the world’s highest criminal court, threatens the national security of the United States and its allies, including Israel.
content: President Trump signed an executive order on Thursday placing sanctions on the International Criminal Court and pledging “tangible and significant consequences” for those responsible for investigations that threatened the national security of the United States and its allies, including Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Hegseth Uses His First Town Hall to Attack Diversity
description: The defense secretary, speaking to the Pentagon work force, defended his “unconventional approaches” to an audience that included women and people of color.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave his first public address to the Pentagon work force on Friday, spending much of the session defending his efforts to dismantle diversity and inclusion policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Surgeons Transplant Engineered Pig Kidney Into Fourth Patient
description: A 66-year-old man from New Hampshire became the fourth person to receive a pig’s kidney.
content: Surgeons in Boston successfully transplanted the kidney of a genetically modified pig into a 66-year-old man with kidney failure last month, Massachusetts General Hospital announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Lydia Polgreen and David French
title: Resistance, Where Art Thou?
description: Protesting Trump isn’t enough this time.
content: Gone are the days of pussy hats and massive protests. Where is the resistance to Donald Trump’s second term?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Adam Goldman, Jonah E. Bromwich and Maggie Haberman
title: At Justice Dept., Trump’s Former Criminal Defender Emerges as His Enforcer
description: As the acting deputy attorney general, Emil Bove has overseen the forced transfers of senior officials and an effort to collect the names of F.B.I. agents who worked on Jan. 6 cases.
content: In the past few weeks, Emil Bove III, the acting No. 2 official at the Justice Department, has summoned senior career officials to his upper-floor office at headquarters to calmly deliver the news they were being transferred, marginalized or otherwise shoved to the exits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Trump Envoy Pushes Lebanon’s New Leaders to Isolate Hezbollah
description: Hezbollah, a powerful Iran-backed militia, has long been the country’s dominant political force and has formed part of the government for decades.
content: A Trump administration envoy to the Middle East pressed Lebanon’s new leaders on Friday to ensure that Hezbollah does not become part of the government, as the country grapples with a fragile cease-fire and violence that could undermine its push for stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Leonardo Coelho
title: Plane Crashes Into Street in Brazil, Killing 2
description: Six people on the ground were also injured by the plane, part of which struck a bus on the road when it crashed in São Paulo.
content: A small plane crashed into a road in São Paulo, Brazil, around 7:20 a.m. local time Friday, killing both people on board and injuring several people on the ground, according to the city’s fire department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Natalie Alcoba
title: Stream Near Buenos Aires Turns Red, ‘Like a River Covered in Blood’
description: A stream south of the Argentine capital turned a freakish vermilion this week, prompting concerns about pollution. Officials said it could be the result of “some type of organic dye.”
content: A stream in a suburb of Buenos Aires, the Argentine capital, turned bright red this week, prompting residents to express concern that industrial chemicals could be to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
title: U.S.A.I.D. Turmoil Threatens Key Aid Supplies to Gaza, Officials Say
description: Washington has funded roughly a third of the aid sent to the enclave since the war began. With most agency workers set to be put on leave, officials say that those supplies are under threat.
content: The Trump administration’s efforts to downsize the United States Agency for International Development have endangered the funding for food, tents and medical treatment for hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in Gaza, according to U.S. officials and workers for humanitarian groups funded by the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Falling for ‘the Same Kind of Weird’
description: When Jessica Papilla’s sister managed Michael Burnett at Starbucks, she had a hunch he and her sibling would hit it off.
content: Jessica Rose Papilla’s older sister, Noelle Papilla, thought her Starbucks co-worker, Michael Leopold Burnett, might be the perfect match for her sister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Live Bird Markets Ordered to Close in New York After Avian Flu Is Found
description: The order affects roughly 80 markets in New York City and in several nearby counties. New Jersey is also asking its live markets to voluntarily clean, disinfect and temporarily close.
content: All live bird markets in New York City and in several nearby counties must close temporarily in hopes of curbing the spread of bird flu, which was detected at some of the markets in the past week, Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar and Judson Jones
title: Winter Storm Marches East, Promising a Snowy Weekend for Many
description: Another winter storm will rush across the Midwest and the Northeast this weekend, bringing snow and ice along the way.
content: After one winter storm moved out of the Northeast on Thursday, leaving behind a glimmer of ice and snow and more than a few canceled school days, the next in line was smashing into the West Coast on Friday. By Saturday, it will have surged east, blanketing another strip of the Midwest and the Northeast with winter weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This week’s picks include an unconventional Lithuanian love story, a small-town Slovakian horror movie, and more.
content: Early in this Lithuanian feature, Dovydas (Kestutis Cicenas), a sign language interpreter, asks out Elena, a choreographer conducting a workshop for deaf dancers, immediately after their first meeting — and they hit it off instantly. Something feels a little off about it all. His gentle confidence, their spontaneous chemistry; it’s all a bit too easy. When movie meet-cutes start out this good, you might as well brace yourself for a twist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donna Barba Higuera
title: Aliens and A.I. Are the Heroes of These Kids’ Sci-Fi Novels
description: In “What Fell From the Sky,” by Adrianna Cuevas, and “Oasis,” by Guojing, the best examples of humanity aren’t necessarily human.
content: In the past few years, my journeys have taken me around the world. My audiences are mostly young people in middle school and high school. No matter the country or continent, they yearn to fit in, to not feel so “different.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colby Smith
title: Why the Job Market Is Giving the Fed Cover to Extend a Pause on Rate Cuts
description: The central bank is grappling with how quickly to lower interest rates after pausing cuts last month.
content: Less than six months ago, Federal Reserve officials were wringing their hands about the state of the labor market. No major cracks had emerged, but monthly jobs growth had slowed and the unemployment rate was steadily ticking higher. In a bid to preserve the economy’s strength, the Fed took the unusual step of lowering interest rates by double the magnitude of its typical moves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Yes to Beer, No to Buyouts
description: Young federal workers gathered at a Washington bar as the deadline to take a buyout loomed.
content: For the 282,000 federal government employees who live in and around Washington, the first weeks of the new Trump administration have been a mix of uncertainty and consternation, as agencies close and job cuts loom. So when the owner of DC9, a local bar and music venue, decided to show his solidarity via rock-bottom prices for a Thursday evening happy hour, a throng of early-career public servants eagerly answered the call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Strauss’s ‘Salome,’ Squeezed Down to Some Clarinets
description: Heartbeat Opera specializes in daring reductions of the classics, and this may be its most implausible undertaking yet.
content: Strauss’s “Salome” begins with a swiftly slithering clarinet flourish, like a snake darting into the undergrowth almost before you see it. The passage is over in a couple of seconds, but it sets the stage for what’s to come: sinuous, nocturnal, elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Lauren Hirsch
title: OpenAI Close to Deal That Values Company at $300 Billion
description: The Japanese conglomerate SoftBank would invest up to $40 billion in the maker of the chatbot ChatGPT.
content: OpenAI is set to complete a $40 billion fund-raising deal that nearly doubles the high-profile company’s valuation from just four months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Millions Will See This Super Bowl Ad. Health Experts (and Two Senators) Aren’t Pleased.
description: The spot makes lofty claims about weight-loss drugs offered by the telehealth company Hims & Hers, but says little about risks.
content: The first thing the ad shows is a scale. Over the soundtrack of Childish Gambino's anthem “This is America,” a narrator laments the nation’s obesity crisis and “the system” that is “built to keep us sick and stuck.” It notes the “$160 billion weight-loss industry that feeds on our failure” as images of junk cereal, pie and a cheeseburger flash across the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Joe Coscarelli, Sydney Harper, Will Reid, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Brendan Klinkenberg, Mike Benoist, Rowan Niemisto, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: The Story of ‘Not Like Us’
description: A look back at Kendrick Lamar’s diss track before his Super Bowl halftime show.
content: A battle between two major artists has been dominating the world of music. It’s a fight over one song — a song that may get its biggest stage ever at this weekend’s Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Trump Signs Order to Fight ‘Anti-Christian Bias’
description: The president convened a task force to “prosecute anti-Christian violence and vandalism.” Critics said he’d turned religious freedom on its head by singling out one faith.
content: President Trump signed an executive order on Thursday aimed at eradicating “anti-Christian bias” in the federal government by having agencies review policies and practices that he says have tried to squelch religious activities and activism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Brooklyn Museum Will Lay Off Employees and Scale Back Exhibitions
description: The museum, which faces a projected $10 million deficit, said it planned to cut more than a tenth of its employees and mount fewer exhibitions.
content: The Brooklyn Museum said Friday that it would soon cut more than 40 employees — between 10 and 13 percent of its work force — to alleviate the pressures of a financial deficit that is projected to reach $10 million by the end of its fiscal year in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: San Francisco Is Latest City to Sue Trump Over Immigration Policies
description: Some local officials are pushing back against the federal government’s assertion that they must help ICE with its deportation campaign.
content: San Francisco said on Friday that it would join several other cities in suing the Trump administration over its efforts to get them to comply with its immigration policies, pushing back against federal directives to punish jurisdictions that resist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Arts Endowment Cuts Grants Dedicated to Underserved Communities
description: The National Endowment for the Arts said it will instead prioritize work that connects with the upcoming 250th anniversary of American independence.
content: The National Endowment for the Arts has eliminated a grant program supporting projects for underserved groups and communities, the latest sign that the Trump administration is quickly putting its stamp on federal arts policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: ‘Demon Copperhead’ Explored Addiction. Its Profits Built a Rehab Center.
description: Barbara Kingsolver has put royalties from her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel to work in the region it portrayed, starting a home for women in recovery.
content: When Barbara Kingsolver was writing “Demon Copperhead,” a novel that explores the devastating effects of the opioid crisis in southern Appalachia, she was doubtful that people would want to read about such a grim subject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Hamas Names 3 Hostages to Be Released in Next Cease-Fire Exchange
description: The Israelis were identified as Eli Sharabi, Or Levy and Ohad Ben-Ami, all of whom were abducted during the 2023 Hamas-led attack. Israel is expected to let dozens of Palestinian prisoners go in return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Rachel Dry, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: The Musketeers Take Washington + Spotify’s Ghost Music + Tool Time
description: “The way to control government is to control the computers”
content: This week, we’re joined by the Times reporter Jonathan Swan to discuss Elon Musk’s tech takeover of Washington, D.C. Then, Liz Pelly, author of a new book about Spotify, stops by to discuss “ghost musicians” and how Spotify’s algorithms are reshaping music culture. And finally — it’s Tool Time! We’ll tell you all about the new A.I. tools we’re using, plus the one that we wish existed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Met Analyzing Stories Like These
description: As Kim Nguyen gathered data on New York Times wedding announcements, she came across Todd Schneider’s analysis of them.
content: Kim Hoang Nguyen was intrigued when she stumbled across Todd William Schneider online. Not because Mr. Schneider, a Yale graduate, screamed marriage material, but rather because of the comprehensive data he collected on a subject she was interested in (according to which, Ivy League graduates were once heavily featured).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Fannie Mae Underpins the Mortgage Market. Should the Government Sell It?
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by the government during the housing crisis nearly 17 years ago. The Trump administration is considering letting them go private again.
content: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two giant mortgage finance firms, have been controlled by the federal government for nearly 17 years, but a long-dormant idea of making them private businesses is starting to make the rounds in Washington again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Scared of Spiders? Also Scared of Zombies? We Have Some Bad News.
description: A BBC documentary crew in Northern Ireland stumbled upon a fungus that hijacks spiders in an arachnid version of “The Last of Us.”
content: An abandoned gunpowder storage shed pokes out from a small mound of earth in what’s now a nature preserve in Northern Ireland. It is the perfect place for a spider: semi-subterranean, cool and dark. But in 2021, a crew working on a BBC nature program found more than an average arachnid lurking there. They spotted a dead spider with a lacy white fungus erupting from its body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norma B. Coe and Rachel M. Werner
title: Your Parents Deserve More From Their Nursing Home
description: New rules requiring increased staffing and care are under attack.
content: For anyone who lives in a nursing home, the adequacy of the nursing staff is a life-or-death issue. That’s why the Biden administration issued federal rules last year setting minimum standards for staffing. By our estimate, they will save 13,000 lives a year. But those rules are now under attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Cade Metz
title: A.I. Military Start-Up Anduril Close to Deal That Would Value It at $28 Billion
description: The Southern California start-up, which builds flying drones and missiles, is set to raise up to $2.5 billion.
content: Anduril, an artificial intelligence military start-up, is set to complete a new round of funding that would double the value of the company to $28 billion, according to four people familiar with the negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: Troubled Volksbühne Theater Announces Another New Director
description: Matthias Lilienthal will take over running the Berlin playhouse, which has been lurching from crisis to crisis for years.
content: Berlin city officials announced Friday that the theater maker Matthias Lilienthal would take over leadership of the Volksbühne, one of Europe’s most influential playhouses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Service Member and 3 Contractors Are Killed in Philippines Plane Crash
description: The plane, which had been contracted by the Pentagon, went down during a routine mission in the southern Philippines, the U.S. military said.
content: A small plane contracted by the Pentagon crashed in the southern Philippines on Thursday, killing all four people aboard, including a member of the U.S. military, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Harlem House Where Billie Holiday Lived Is Damaged in Fire
description: The jazz legend lived in the five-story building on West 139th Street as a teenager with her mother.
content: A four-alarm fire on Wednesday evening severely damaged a building in Harlem where the jazz legend Billie Holiday once lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Mort Künstler, Renowned Painter of Epic Historical Scenes, Dies at 97
description: His years illustrating pulp novels honed his sense of pictorial drama, and his meticulous research ensured historical accuracy, notably in his Civil War paintings.
content: Mort Künstler, whose meticulously researched and dramatically composed paintings of American historical scenes, especially of the Civil War, made him one of the country’s most prominent historical artists, died on Sunday in Rockville Centre, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Trump Calls Directly for Closure of U.S.A.I.D.
description: The president’s demand to end the U.S. Agency for International Development came as the vast majority of the agency’s employees were expecting to be placed on indefinite administrative leave.
content: President Trump on Friday directly called for the closure of the U.S. Agency for International Development just hours before most of its staff were expected to be suspended with pay or laid off, the latest sign that his administration will dissolve the government’s main provider of global humanitarian and development aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Love Hurts’ Review: A Valentine Full of Action
description: Ke Huy Quan and Ariana DeBose play reunited former associates from a criminal outfit. Sparks don’t exactly fly.
content: In “Love Hurts,” Ke Huy Quan plays a cheery, cookie-baking real estate agent who has tried hard to forget his past life as an assassin. Ariana DeBose plays a former associate who emerges from the shadows and reminds him of what he’s left behind, in a movie that does its utmost to repress any memories of both stars’ being recent Academy Award winners.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The president signed an executive order that said the I.C.C.’s actions against Israel and preliminary investigations into the United States “set a dangerous precedent.”
content: President Trump signed an executive order on Thursday placing sanctions on the International Criminal Court, saying that his administration would “impose tangible and significant consequences” on people who work on investigations that threaten the national security of the United States and its allies, including Israel.

description: The shooter targeted a center that serves migrants seeking to integrate into a country that had already reversed its liberal migration policies.
content: Salim Iskef had just bought a house and his upcoming wedding was going to be the high point of the life he was building in Sweden, a decade after escaping war in Syria.

title: N.Y.U. Parent Has an Idea: Deport Hamas Supporters on Campus
description: The founder of Mothers Against College Antisemitism advised the group’s over 61,000 followers to take advantage of a new executive order allowing the deportation of Hamas supporters.
content: The day after the presidential inauguration last month, Elizabeth Rand, the founder of an organization called Mothers Against College Antisemitism — or MACA — posted a note to the more than 61,000 members of the affiliated Facebook group notifying them that: “We now have an executive order authorizing the deportation of foreign students who support Hamas.” She advised followers to take advantage of it and to file complaints against students and faculty members who supported Hamas’s efforts, providing a link to a tip line for the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Transgender Americans Challenge Trump’s Passport Policy in Court
description: The A.C.L.U. filed a lawsuit after the president’s administration stopped issuing passports that reflect the gender identity of transgender and nonbinary people.
content: Seven transgender American citizens sued President Trump and the State Department in federal court on Friday, arguing that a new policy that prevents people from changing gender markers on passports violates their constitutional rights.

title: Grenfell Tower Was a Death Trap. Some Wanted It to Stand as a Warning.
description: Britain’s government confirmed Friday that the tower block in London, where 72 people died, would be demolished, provoking a combination of anger and relief from survivors and bereaved families.
content: For nearly eight years, wrapped in white and crowned with green hearts, Grenfell Tower has stood as a tragic monument to the worst residential fire in the post-World War II history of Britain. On Friday, the government confirmed it would demolish the building, where 72 people died in a blaze that a public inquiry blamed on a lethal combination of negligence, cost-cutting and deregulation.
